articles.headline: Old Friends Say Drugs Played Bit Part in Obama’s Young Life
articles.snippet: Barack Obama has admitted to using illegal drugs as a teenager, but others remember him as a model of moderation.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama has admitted to using illegal drugs as a teenager, but others remember him as a model of moderation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly three decades ago, Barack Obama stood out on the small campus of Occidental College in Los Angeles for his eloquence, intellect and activism against apartheid in South Africa. But Mr. Obama, then known as Barry, also joined in the party scene.

articles.headline: Debt Relief Can Cause Headaches of Its Own
articles.snippet: With the economy slowing and houses no longer easy sources of cash, a growing number of consumers cannot pay the minimum monthly amount off their credit card debt.
articles.abstract: With the economy slowing and houses no longer easy sources of cash, a growing number of consumers cannot pay the minimum monthly amount off their credit card debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: It wasn’t supposed to work this way.

articles.headline: 6 at Guantánamo Said to Face Trial in 9/11 Case
articles.snippet: A sweeping case against suspects in the Sept. 11 attacks would bring new scrutiny to military commissions.
articles.abstract: A sweeping case against suspects in the Sept. 11 attacks would bring new scrutiny to military commissions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Military prosecutors are in the final phases of preparing the first sweeping case against suspected conspirators in the plot that led to the deaths of nearly 3,000 Americans on Sept. 11, 2001, and drew the United States into war, people who have been briefed on the case said.

articles.headline: In Venezuela, Faith in Chávez Starts to Wane
articles.snippet: As economic and social problems grow acute, President Hugo Chávez is facing criticism even from his supporters.
articles.abstract: As economic and social problems grow acute, President Hugo Chávez is facing criticism even from his supporters.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela  These should be the best of times for Venezuela, blessed with the largest conventional oil reserves outside the Middle East and oil prices near record highs. But this country’s economic and social problems have become so acute lately that President Hugo Chávez is facing an unusual onslaught of criticism, even from his own supporters, about his management of the country.

articles.headline: From Japan’s Slump in 1990s, Lessons for U.S.
articles.snippet: A Japan-style quagmire, most economists say, is an outcome that can be avoided in the United States with sound economic policy.
articles.abstract: A Japan-style quagmire, most economists say, is an outcome that can be avoided in the United States with sound economic policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: In broad strokes, the parallels are alarming. After a long boom, the Japanese economy in the 1990s, as America’s today, was jolted by a sharp plunge in the real estate market.

articles.headline: The Race to Read Genomes on a Shoestring, Relatively Speaking
articles.snippet: If the cost of sequencing a human genome can drop to $1,000 or below, experts say it would start to become feasible to tell what diseases people might be at risk for.
articles.abstract: If the cost of sequencing a human genome can drop to $1,000 or below, experts say it would start to become feasible to tell what diseases people might be at risk for.

articles.headline: Facing Free Software, Microsoft Looks to Yahoo
articles.snippet: Internet-centered programs that compete with the core products of Microsoft are a driver of its bid for Yahoo.
articles.abstract: Internet-centered programs that compete with the core products of Microsoft are a driver of its bid for Yahoo.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Nearly a quarter-century ago, the mantra “information wants to be free” heralded an era in which news, entertainment and personal communications would flow at no charge over the Internet.

articles.headline: 2nd Trader Emerges in Inquiry in France
articles.snippet: The man French authorities were questioning was identified as Moussa Bakir, a broker at Société Générale’s futures brokerage unit.
articles.abstract: The man French authorities were questioning was identified as Moussa Bakir, a broker at Société Générale’s futures brokerage unit.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  French investigators said Friday that they were questioning a second trader in connection with Société Générale’s 5 billion euro ($7.1 billion) loss, the worst in history caused by a rogue trader.
articles.byline: By Nicola Clark and Katrin Bennhold

articles.headline: A Tight Grip Can Choke Creativity
articles.snippet: A small book publisher faces off against the titans in a Harry Potter copyright case.
articles.abstract: A small book publisher faces off against the titans in a Harry Potter copyright case.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Friday, a lawyer named Anthony Falzone filed his side’s first big brief in the case of Warner Bros. Entertainment and J. K. Rowling v. RDR Books. Mr. Falzone is employed by Stanford Law School, where he heads up the Fair Use Project, which was founded several years ago by Lawrence Lessig, perhaps the law school’s best-known professor. Mr. Falzone and the other lawyers at the Fair Use Project are siding with the defendant, RDR Books, a small book publisher based in Muskegon, Mich. As you can see from the titans who have brought the suit, RDR Books needs all the legal firepower it can muster.

articles.headline: Bush Presses for G.O.P. Unity; Party Set to Focus on Security
articles.snippet: The president said that the election would offer a stark ideological choice.
articles.abstract: The president said that the election would offer a stark ideological choice.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Offering a preview of the general election campaign, President Bush sought on Friday to unify the Republican Party behind its presumptive nominee and said the contest would present the country with a stark ideological choice at a time of war.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Michael Cooper

articles.headline: Vocal  Contest Gives McDonald’s Employees Something to Sing About
articles.snippet: The “American Idol” craze has spawned an elaborate knock-off at McDonald’s, which put out a casting call to its workers and was overwhelmed by 3,600 video auditions.
articles.abstract: The “American Idol” craze has spawned an elaborate knock-off at McDonald’s, which put out a casting call to its workers and was overwhelmed by 3,600 video auditions.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUNMORE, Pa. Might as well call it “Corporate Idol.”

articles.headline: Writers Reach Tentative Deal With Producers
articles.snippet: The strike remains in effect until the governing boards of the two writers’ guilds gauge the sense of their membership on both coasts.
articles.abstract: The strike remains in effect until the governing boards of the two writers’ guilds gauge the sense of their membership on both coasts.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  An end to Hollywood’s long and bitter writers’ strike appeared close on Saturday, as union leaders representing 12,000 movie and television writers said they had reached a tentative three-year deal with production companies.

articles.headline: Neck and Neck, Democrats Woo Superdelegates
articles.snippet: The Clinton and Obama campaigns are aggressively pursuing members of a group that could decide the outcome at the convention.
articles.abstract: The Clinton and Obama campaigns are aggressively pursuing members of a group that could decide the outcome at the convention.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Seeing a good possibility that the Democratic presidential nomination will not be settled in the primaries and caucuses, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama are lavishing attention on a group that might hold the balance of power: elected officials and party leaders who could decide the outcome at the convention in August.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Cutting to the Quick
articles.snippet: While lower rates are always a positive for banks, the effects of the Fed’s cuts may not prompt an immediate rebound in profits at many banks.
articles.abstract: While lower rates are always a positive for banks, the effects of the Fed’s cuts may not prompt an immediate rebound in profits at many banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WITH the Federal Reserve busy cutting interest rates, investors in financial services companies are surely hoping that their beleaguered stocks will rebound. That has been the outcome after previous Fed rescue efforts, of course, and for good reason. When the capital costs of large commercial banks decline significantly, it is far easier for them to generate profits: for example, they lend at much higher rates than their cost or invest in higher-yielding securities.

articles.headline: The Job Interview, Starring Your Avatar
articles.snippet: As big companies spread their brands to Web-based social networking communities, some employers are also exploring Multi-User Virtual Environments, or MUVEs.
articles.abstract: As big companies spread their brands to Web-based social networking communities, some employers are also exploring Multi-User Virtual Environments, or MUVEs.
articles.lead_paragraph: AS far as job interviews go, my recent meeting with Sandy Gould was anything but ordinary.

articles.headline: Terror Threat From Pakistan Said to Expand
articles.snippet: A suspected bombing plot in Spain is indicative of an important threat coming from Pakistan, officials said.
articles.abstract: A suspected bombing plot in Spain is indicative of an important threat coming from Pakistan, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Elaine Sciolino, Victoria Burnett and Eric Schmitt and written by Ms. Sciolino.

articles.headline: Pushing Paper Out the Door
articles.snippet: After rising steadily in the 1980s and ’90s, worldwide paper consumption per capita has plateaued in recent years.
articles.abstract: After rising steadily in the 1980s and ’90s, worldwide paper consumption per capita has plateaued in recent years.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHRIS UHLIK’S children can be found in their home computer lab almost every morning. Nicole is writing a story about her two lizards. Tony is playing an interactive spelling game, while Andy is learning multiplication tables. Even 5-year-old Joceline is clicking away at a storybook game.

articles.headline: Will Disney Keep Us Amused?
articles.snippet: Disney is revamping one of its California theme parks by melding classic carnival games with virtual reality.
articles.abstract: Disney is revamping one of its California theme parks by melding classic carnival games with virtual reality.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif.  VISIT Disney’s California Adventure  a 55-acre theme park next door to the fabled progenitor of the modern amusement Mecca, Disneyland  and you will find a noisy reminder of what happens when a company loses its focus and cuts corners.

articles.headline: Obama Scores Convincing Wins in Three States
articles.snippet: Barack Obama beat Hillary Rodham Clinton in contests in Louisiana, Nebraska and Washington State as Mike Huckabee showed that he is still attracting Republican voters.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama beat Hillary Rodham Clinton in contests in Louisiana, Nebraska and Washington State as Mike Huckabee showed that he is still attracting Republican voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Barack Obama won decisive victories over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in Washington, Louisiana and Nebraska on Saturday, giving him an impressive sweep going into a month when the Democratic nominating contests are expected to favor him.

articles.headline: U.S. Wonders if Stock Deal Is Tax Abuse
articles.snippet: A strategy executives use to turn their stockholdings into cash while delaying payment of taxes is coming under increased scrutiny by the Internal Revenue Service.
articles.abstract: A strategy executives use to turn their stockholdings into cash while delaying payment of taxes is coming under increased scrutiny by the Internal Revenue Service.
articles.lead_paragraph: A strategy that corporate executives routinely use to turn their stockholdings into cash while delaying payment of taxes is coming under increased scrutiny by the Internal Revenue Service.

articles.headline: Kenya’s Middle Class Feeling Sting of Violence
articles.snippet: The well-established middle class is thought to be one of the factors that separates Kenya from other African countries that have been consumed by ethnic conflict.
articles.abstract: The well-established middle class is thought to be one of the factors that separates Kenya from other African countries that have been consumed by ethnic conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya  George G. Mbugua is a 42-year-old executive with two cars, a closet full of suits and a good job as the chief financial officer of a growing company.

articles.headline: Maine to Obama; Clinton Replaces Campaign Leader
articles.snippet: Facing another big round of contests Tuesday, Hillary Rodham Clinton conducted the biggest shakeup of her campaign to date as Barack Obama tallied another win.
articles.abstract: Facing another big round of contests Tuesday, Hillary Rodham Clinton conducted the biggest shakeup of her campaign to date as Barack Obama tallied another win.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIRGINIA BEACH  Senator Barack Obama racked up his fourth decisive victory this weekend, winning the Maine caucuses on Sunday, as Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton replaced her campaign manager and longtime aide in the biggest shakeup of her campaign to date.

articles.headline: Between States, Hard Feelings Over a Rock’s Place
articles.snippet: When a man removed an eight-ton rock from the Ohio River, those on the opposite bank objected.
articles.abstract: When a man removed an eight-ton rock from the Ohio River, those on the opposite bank objected.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTSMOUTH, Ohio

articles.headline: Trading Pinstripes for Politics
articles.snippet: Changes at The Wall Street Journal: movable deadlines and a new taste for models.
articles.abstract: Changes at The Wall Street Journal: movable deadlines and a new taste for models.
articles.lead_paragraph: You’ve been dating the same person for years. She’s not flashy, but she is steady and, to your mind, glorious. And then you begin to notice changes. A slimmer profile, a suddenly increased concern with appearances. You keep your suspicions to yourself, but it soon becomes obvious that everything is changing. And you finally just blurt it out.

articles.headline: How Sticky Is Membership on Facebook? Just Try Breaking Free
articles.snippet: Some members discover it’s tough to erase all their information from the site.
articles.abstract: Some members discover it’s tough to erase all their information from the site.
articles.lead_paragraph: Are you a member of Facebook.com? You may have a lifetime contract.

articles.headline: Theory Gains That Trader Had a Helper
articles.snippet: The investigation into the $7.2 billion trading scandal at Société Générale appears to be aiming toward a theory that the bank’s rogue trader might not have acted alone.
articles.abstract: The investigation into the $7.2 billion trading scandal at Société Générale appears to be aiming toward a theory that the bank’s rogue trader might not have acted alone.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  The police investigating the trading scandal at Société Générale were moving on Sunday toward a theory that its rogue trader, whom the bank blames for losing it nearly $7.2 billion, might not have acted alone, as he and the bank have claimed.
articles.byline: By Nicola Clark and Katrin Bennhold

articles.headline: Putting Candidates Under the Videoscope
articles.snippet: Equipped with laptops and hand-held video cameras, off-air network reporters, or embeds, are catching every unplugged and unscripted moment on the campaign trail.
articles.abstract: Equipped with laptops and hand-held video cameras, off-air network reporters, or embeds, are catching every unplugged and unscripted moment on the campaign trail.
articles.lead_paragraph: One late night last November, Mitt Romney, campaigning in Greenville, S.C., was approached by three young women in bright matching outfits looking for a hug. Mr. Romney, thinking they were cheerleaders from nearby Clemson University, obliged.

articles.headline: Yahoo Bidder Wants a More Aggressive Microsoft
articles.snippet: With Yahoo’s board rejecting Microsoft’s bid, it will fall to Christopher P. Liddell, an outsider to the software industry, to plot Microsoft’s next steps in the bitter battle.
articles.abstract: With Yahoo’s board rejecting Microsoft’s bid, it will fall to Christopher P. Liddell, an outsider to the software industry, to plot Microsoft’s next steps in the bitter battle.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Yahoo sends its letter rejecting Microsoft’s $44.6 billion on Monday, it will end up in the inbox of a largely unknown executive on Microsoft’s sprawling campus, Christopher P. Liddell.

articles.headline: U.S. Seeking Execution for 6 in Sept. 11 Case
articles.snippet: The decision to seek the death penalty for detainees would present challenges to a troubled military commission system that has yet to begin a single trial.
articles.abstract: The decision to seek the death penalty for detainees would present challenges to a troubled military commission system that has yet to begin a single trial.
articles.lead_paragraph: Military prosecutors have decided to seek the death penalty for six Guantánamo detainees who are to be charged with central roles in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, government officials who have been briefed on the charges said Sunday.
